interlinear-text.item: GSK tawallidi batsʃa - za tər bar niçvak [3]

phrase.item: Birth of a child
If a boy is born, that same day women bring over leguminous flour.
The men celebrate the event by firing their guns.
They say: "May God almighty bless the new guest.
Throne and happiness, green base (?), long life.
Allah is great.
This is how they pray.
Then we slaughter a sheep.
The elderly come to eat it and read this prayer.
When a girl is born we don't fire guns, we scatter leguminous flour.
We slaughter a sheep and we organize a light meal.
Here is everything that has to do with a birth.
First Haircut
Once he [the child] is a year old, we invite over the neighbors.
People come and bring him shirts, fabric, butter, [and] ptoks (little traditional, ritual breads)
We slaughter a sheep and we bring the child.
We clean his head and face with care.
Next we take scissors and each person cuts off a tuft of hair.
This is what we cut off of him and each person offers him a shirt, a tree or a sheep, or even a cow.
We give all of this to the boy or girl, i.e. first we promise and next we give.
Then we bring dishes [of food]: pilaf or meat or rice porridge.
We prepare these dishes, we bring them over and we serve them.
We eat, we get up and we go.
Circumcision
When the circumcision master arrives, we bring the child, we clean him in water, [and] we dress him in a garment.
Then the master performes the circumcision.
Next we organize a meal and we slaughter a sheep.
We give the master money, fabric, socks, [and] a skullcap
He takes this and goes.
Child's first time out
When the child is six months or a year old, first we prepare it for the performance of an ancient ritual: we prepare a sheep, rice, other foods, and a garment.
Then we invite the parents, acquaintances, and the close neighbors.
We fry (grill) wheat grains, we dress the child in a garment.
Some old man and some old woman powder the child with leguminous flour.
If there is a literate [person], he reads.
First we take "the book of prayers and cures", then we carry the child out of the door into the fresh air for five to ten minutes.
From that day forward, when the weather is nice, we bring the child outside constantly (regularly).
